p.s: The relationship between Abe and Amir takes a big developing step in the fourth scene.
Abe is Amir's nephew and both have a Muslim background.
Whereas Amir changed his name from Abdullah and also resented his Muslim fate, Abe decides to changchange back his name to Hussein and wants to live a Muslim lifestyle.
Both of them live in the fear of racism and therefore tried to fit into American society.
It turns out their fears are rightful because Abe was taken in by the FBIFederal Bureau of Investigation because of his Muslim look.
One can see that they have different thoughts and opinions but are also both victims of American racist society.
Abe has developed a negative view on the American government.
After he got taken in and the FBIFederal Bureau of Investigation checked his immigration status, he laughed (l. 4).
It shows that he doesn't have respect for American authorities anymore.
He also thinks they're looking for people whose immigration is vulnerable.Then they push us to start doing stuff for them (l. 10-11).
Amir doesn't disagree on that (l. 13-14) but thinks it's not clever that Abe laughed.
He thinks Abe wanted to antagonize them (l. 7).
Here it gets clear that Amir still has big fear and respect of the American authorities.
Abe on the other hand, developed a strong mindset and questions the American authorities.
It gets clearer when Amir says that There are ways... to let the authorities know that ... you're on their side (l. 31-32), after Abe asks him what he would do in Abe's situation.
Abe makes his position clear saying But I'm not on their side (l. 33).

One can see that Amir tries to convince Abe of his perspective because Amir wants to protect Abe and not because he doesn't like or share Abe's opinion, when Amir says It's not a mistake, but If you're not smarter about this, you're going to get deported (l. 36).
However Abe still doesn't want to change his opinion and is arguing that it wouldn't be the worst thing (l. 38) to get deported.
The scene finds it'sits climax when Amir tries to explain to Abe that the reason Abe's and his father came to America, was to live a better life.
Abe explodes and answers with You don't have a better life! (l. 46) and then going on with saying that he knows Amir got fired and that he beat up Emily.
From that point on their relationship get unstable and they talk to each other in a rage.
Abe questions Amir and his loyalty to who he really is (l. 67) and tells him he changed his name back which also causes Amir being triggered and escalating.
When Amir is telling how he feels about Abe living a Muslim lifestyle and that he doesn't think it's the right way, Abe interrupts him and counters with what he thinks.
They both don't have respect for each other anymore and let out what they think about each other, without thinking about it before.
Because of that Abe tells Amir, he doesn't look up to him anymore aswell as that he finds it disgusting (l. 66) how Amir turns on his own people.
He goes on comparing Amir to the prophet and that he wouldn't be trying to be like one of them (l. 69).
That again not only shows the disrespect of Abe to Amir, but also that Abe is really dealing with the Islam.
Having said what he wanted to say, Abe tells Amir he will handle it himself and leaves.
It highlights how Abe and Amir's relationship has collapsed in that conversation.
Abe exits with naming Amir uncle (l. 75).
It expresses even further how their relationship had a massive downfall with Abe not calling Amir by his name.
He could also have done that because he thinks Amir's name isn't his real, reflecting what he said before, namely, that Amir isn't loyal and so on.
In conclusion one can say that Amir and Abe's relationship had a negative development throughout the scene.
Whereas in the beginning they were nephew and uncle with a healthy relationship and Abe even looking up to Amir, in the end just family and blood connects them.
